titleStmt.title: The computational optimality of implementation intentions for goal pursuit

analytic.title: The computational optimality of implementation intentions for goal pursuit

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Implementation Intentions are precise IF-THEN plans about when and where in the future one will initiate goal pursuit. A volume of evidence encompassing social, cognitive, and applied psychology has established Implementation Intentions as an effective strategy for goal pursuit over simply intending to pursue a goal (Goal Intentions). In this Perspective, we propose a computational framework for intention formation (Implementation vs. Goal vs. No Intention) and how it impacts goal pursuit. Our framework explains a broad range of findings within the intention formation literature including seemingly contradictory ones, while making novel empirically testable predictions. Importantly, it establishes normative conditions under which forming Implementation (vs. Goal) Intentions is an optimal strategy considering its benefits and costs. Finally, current formal models of value-based decision-making rarely consider ecological timescales of human intentions. Interfacing with this work, we lay the groundwork for a neurocognitive understanding of intention formation and its impact on goal pursuit.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: You remember an old friend whom you have not been in touch with for a while. So, you form an intention "I will call my friend today." Folk intuition and foundational work in psychology both indicate that forming such a Goal Intention (GOI) would increase your likelihood of calling your friend over routine behaviour, compared to when you had not formed such an intention [1][2][3][4][5][6] . Alternatively, upon remembering your friend, you may form a more precise intention, like "After I finish having dinner today, I will call my friend." Such an intention that specifies when or where one wants to execute a behaviour in the future has come to be known in psychology as an Implementation Intention 7,8 (IMPI). A wealth of evidence in social and cognitive psychology has shown that IMPIs increase the likelihood of intended behaviour over and above GOIs [9][10][11] . This work has established IMPIs as a robust method for self-regulation applied across a broad range of goaldirected behaviours spanning diverse cognitive domains [12][13][14][15][16][17][18][19] . However, while psychological research on intention formation (Implementation vs. Goal vs. No Intention) has flourished over past decades, little progress has been made to understand the computational underpinnings of how intention formation supports future goal pursuit.

Parallelly, recent decades have seen rapid advances in computational cognitive neuroscience research on planning and goal-directed behaviour [20][21][22][23][24][25][26][27] . This body of work has formalized models of how people plan to attain rewards (a proxy for goals) along with brain mechanisms that support such planning 25,26,[28][29][30] . Such models are devised to explain behaviours of how people maximise rewards in the "myopic" 31 upcoming future. They rarely consider real-world type situations where humans plan to execute behaviours over much longer time scales, ranging from minutes to days, months, or even years (except see 31,32 ). Accordingly, such models do not consider whether a plan or an intention is followed up in the more distant future and how following up on intentions is impacted by non-reward-based strategies (like IMPIs). A formal computational understanding of intention formation would thus further our understanding of how people can make effective plans about a farther, more uncertain, future.

In this Perspective, we address above issues through a synthesis of psychological research on intention formation with computational cognitive science. In the following sections, we first introduce social psychology literature on intention formation with a focus on its putative mechanisms. Next, we present a general computational framework for intention formation that explains diverse findings in literature, including seemingly contradictory ones. We then review neurocognitive work on planning and sequential decision-making to propose the neurocognitive mechanisms through which our framework may be realised. Finally, we outline directions for future research.

div.head: Implementation Intentions and their mechanisms
div.p: Intending to pursue goals in the long-term is fundamental to human functioning. However, following up on one's GOIs is not trivial, as intended behaviours necessarily compete with otherwise routines behaviours 8 . For example, your intention to call your friend may be hindered by the set of routine behaviours you perform every day, like job, meals, leisure, and sleep ( Figure 1A). Reviewing a vast literature on intention-behaviour correlations, Sheeran and colleagues found that forming GOIs explains only about 3-7% variance of pursued goals, leaving a substantial unexplained "intention-behaviour gap" 1,10,33 .

As a potential improvement to goal pursuit over and above GOIs, Peter Gollwitzer introduced the idea of an IMPI where an intention is supplemented by an IF-THEN plan about how and where one will pursue the goal in the future 7,8 . In a series of studies, Gollwitzer and colleagues showed that the likelihood of goal attainment was considerably improved by using IMPIs [34][35][36][37] . An early study by Gollwitzer and Brandstätter (1997) illustrates a typical experimental format for testing if forming IMPIs benefits goal pursuit 34 . Here, student participants were tasked to write a report over Christmas break about how they spent their Christmas eve -a GOI. Half the participants were additionally asked to specify to the experimenters when and where they would write the report -an IMPI. By the end of the break, 32% participants in the GOI group (those who did not form an IMPI) had completed the report. On the other hand, in the IMPI group the report completion rate was more than twice the GOI group, at 71%. Since this early work, hundreds of published studies have used IMPI instructions and tested if they enhance goal pursuit and goal attainment in relation to diverse sets of behaviours and domains 10,11,33 . Meta-analyses show that intention formation, and particularly IMPIs, are effective for physical exercise 38,39 , emotional regulation 40 , eating behaviours 41,42 , prospective memory 43,44 , mental health 45 , smoking cessation 46,47 , alcohol consumption 48,49 , and sports performance 50 .

Researchers have also investigated mechanisms of how IMPIs improve goal pursuit. One potentially straightforward explanation would be that IMPIs improve goal striving. This could happen because, when compared to a GOI, a more detailed IMPI may increase people's commitment or motivation towards a goal 2,51 , increase their self-efficacy or confidence in pursuing it 52,53 , or decrease its perceived difficulty 54,55 . However, a metaanalysis of 34 studies found no empirical evidence that IMPIs work through such enhanced motivational processes 56 . Indeed, studies that explicitly compare instructions emphasizing motivation (e.g., expected reward) with an IMPI find a distinct benefit for the latter over former in goal pursuit 51,57 . Thus, while motivation or striving in relation to a goal undeniably improves its pursuit, such a mechanism is not thought to underlie IMPIs.

Gollwitzer and colleagues put forth a different explanation for the mechanistic basis for IMPIs 7,10 . According to them, the key to IMPIs is the IF-THEN plan of the intention. Such a plan helps forge a strong association in the mental representations of a contextual cue (the IF component) and the goal-directed behaviour (THEN component), through, for example, a "mental simulation" that relates the cue to the goal 58 . Then, when a person encounters the cue in their environment -i.e., the context (place, time, or behaviour) in relation to which the goal was intended to be pursued -representations of the goal and its associated preplanned behaviour become easily accessible to them 10,56 . This in turn makes it more likely for people to pursue goals in the cued context. Returning to the Christmas report example, of the participants who received the IMPI instructions, 83% of the participants completed the report on the day they had planned. This indicates a high specificity of goal pursual linked to the contextual cue set by the IMPI. This contextualcue-with-goal matching mechanism is further supported by work showing that, when compared to GOIs, IMPIs make goal retrieval/pursual relatively automatic. This includes, initiating goal pursuit despite the presence of cognitive load 36,59,60 , in the absence of conscious awareness 61,62 and with immediacy 34,37,63 . For these reasons, IMPIs have also been described as forming "instant habits" 9 .

A substantial volume of intention formation literature has also investigated conditions that moderate the impact of IMPIs on goal pursual 55,64,65 (i.e., make IMPIs more or less effective when compared to GOIs). Two sets of observations are salient in this literature 55,66 . The first set of observations is that the benefit of forming IMPIs over GOIs is larger with higher baseline levels of GOIs 61,[67][68][69][70][71][72] . This is interpreted as, with higher motivation for the goal, there is also a larger increase in goal pursuit using an IF-THEN plan over a simple GOI. A second set of observations (that seemingly contradict the first) is that factors that make it highly likely for a person to pursue a goal are less benefited by IMPIs. For example, conscientious people who already achieve their goal with high likelihood benefit less from IMPI than less conscientious people 73 . Similarly, IMPIs are less effective when goals are easy to attain compared to more difficult goals 34,54,59,74 . Interestingly though, one study found that both easy and difficult goals can benefit from IMPIs as long as there is no ceiling effect in pursuing easy goals 75 (i.e., the easy goals are not too easy).

Past work has primarily focused on IMPIs improving goal pursuit in relation to the contextual cue specified in the IMPI. However, if IMPIs increase goal pursuit in relation to particular to contextual cues, an ideal strategy for people would be to also suppress goal pursuit in the non-cued contexts, which are then freed up to pursue other routines and goals. A consequence of such a strategy would be that if a person does not encounter the IMPI cue (or misses goal pursuit when the cue is encountered), they may be less likely to pursue the goal in the non-cued scenarios as compared to people who form GOIs 76 . A few studies have investigated this idea and confirmed that associating goals with specific cues using IMPIs hamper goal-pursuit when the cue is missed compared to GOIs [77][78][79] . These findings further inform a mechanistic view of IMPIs, where setting a cue-specific association with the goal entails a suppression of the association between the goal and non-cued contexts.

div.head: A computational framework for intention formation
div.p: So far, a mechanistic inquiry of intention formation has only used descriptive models -e.g., GOIs operate by increasing motivation or IMPIs operate by strengthening the association between a contextual cue and goal-directed behaviour. In recent years, there has been a growing emphasis on understanding psychological phenomena using computational models due to their advantages over descriptive models [80][81][82][83][84] . Computational models are mathematical/algorithmic formalisations of descriptive models. Such models aim to, one the one hand, explain (rather than just describe) data in terms of its proposed mechanistic sources, and on the other, make testable predictions for ascertaining the goodness of models and how different models compare with each other 81,82 . As a result, computational modelling aids theory development 82,85 , conceptual clarity 83 , and is posed as part of the solution to the replication crisis in psychology 82,86 . Computational modelling can moreover allow us to understand complex data patterns that are common to psychological data in terms of simpler hidden underlying sources 80,83,87 . In relation to intention formation, for example, a computational model may be able to illustrate simpler mechanistic reasons for the apparently complex interplay between GOIs and IMPIs observed in literature (e.g., the different directions of moderation effects outlined above) 55,64,65 . Importantly, given that IMPIs both increase and decrease goal pursuit in cued and non-cued contexts respectively, a computational model would help delineate conditions under which forming an IMPI is an optimal strategy compared to a GOI within a resource-rational view of the mind [88][89][90] . In other words, because there are both advantages and costs associated with forming IMPIs, under what conditions should a rational person (who takes into account the costs) use an IMPI strategy for goal pursuit?

We propose a computational framework 1 for intention formation and how intention formation relates to goal pursuit in the future. To illustrate the framework, we return to the example of a person intending to call their friend on the same day. Figure 1A shows a series of routine behaviours that a person performs after returning from work depicted as a sequence of punctate states. In their routine, the person returns home from work ( ! ), prepares dinner ( " ), has dinner ( # ), watches TV ( $ ), and then goes to sleep ( % ). Among these routine behavioural states, the person intends to pursue the goal of calling their friend ( & ). Here, for simplicity (and without losing generalization) we have assumed that in each routine state the person chooses between only two subsequent states, 1) the next routine state, and 2) the intended goal state.

In its most general form, there are at least two factors that would determine how a person No Set Intention (blue), Goal Intention (orange) and Implementation Intention (purple). A punctate depiction of example routine states (s1-s5) that a person performs after returning from work, along with the intended goal state (sg) of calling one's friend (for ease of visualisation we do not show return arrows indicating transitions from sg to subsequent routine states, which are also otherwise present). Numbers along the arrows towards sg are probabilities that one will "Call friend" under different intention scenarios from each routine state (before going to sleep). In the absence of a set intention, the probability of arriving at sg is low from all routine states. With a Goal Intention, the probability of arriving at sg is roughly equivalent from all routine states and depends on the subjective value of the intention. With an Implementation Intention, the probability of arriving at sg is high from a specific cued state (here, scue = s3) and low from all other routine states. B) The probability of pursuing the goal ( !"#$ ; y-axis) of calling one's friend as a function of state-specificity ( ; x-axis) with each line reflecting subjective value of the goal ( ! ). Here, = 1 corresponds to a Goal Intention and > 1 reflects an Implementation Intention that gets increasingly specific to the cued state. The three panels reflect different values of the suppression exponent ( ). The value of determines if the suppression of match of the non-cued states is less than (left), equal to (middle) or more than (right) the increase in match of the cued state with the goal.

div.head: High
div.p: Low "Right after dinner today, I will call my friend" picks a subsequent state (either routine or intended) following the current one. First, the contextual match (i.e., associative strength) between the current state and possible subsequent states ( ), and second, how rewarding, valuable, or important the subsequent state is to the person ( ; here value can also be replaced with different aspects of goal striving, such as motivation, self-efficacy, or perceived difficulty of the goal). With minimal assumptions, the probability of transitioning to the intended goal state, & , from a current routine state, ' , can be written as the product of the contextual match and value parameters for the intended goal state normalized by the sum of products of value and contextual match of all possible subsequent states (here there are only two such states):

div.head: Goal Intention Implementation Intention
div.p: Here, & and '(! are respectively the values of the intended goal state and subsequent routine state. & and '(! are respectively the contextual match of the goal state and the subsequent routine state with the current state. In Box 1, we show how this equation is a simplified form of our recent model of intention selection (MIS) 91,92 , which outlines a computational framework for how one of many action plans, which includes intentions and routine behaviours, are chosen from long-term memory 93 .
Conversely, the probability that one pursues a subsequent routine state will be simply,

Using Equations (1) and (2), we propose that intention formation involves a person engaging in two processes. First, setting the subjective value of the intended goal ( & ) or how important the goal is to the person. And second, setting the state-specificity ( ) of the intention. In the absence of state-specificity, the goal is intended to be pursued following any of the future predicted states such that it is not tied to any specific contextual cue. This would be the case when a person only forms a GOI. As statespecificity increases, one intends to pursue the goal cued by a specific state, )*+ ; this would be the case of an IMPI. Moreover, state-specificity entails the goal not being pursued in association with the non-cued contextual states. State-specificity can thus be formalised in relation to the contextual match between intended goal state and routine behavioural states, as follows:

where ≥ 1 and ≥ 0. For = 1, contextual match with the goal state will be the same for all preceding routine states (i.e., & = 1 for both = )*+ and ≠ )*+ ). This situation reflects the case of a GOI. With > 1, the contextual match increases with cued state invoked in an IMPI (i.e., )*+ ) while decreasing with all the other (non-cued) states. We also introduce a suppression exponent, , which determines the degree to which noncued states are suppressed relative to the increased contextual match of the cued state. For = 0, & = 1 for non-cued states, implying that there is no suppression of goal pursuit in the non-cued states (despite an increase in the cued state by ). Goal pursuit is increasingly suppressed with non-cued states as increases such that the suppression factor (i.e., , ) is smaller (0 < < 1), equal to ( = 1), or larger ( > 1) than the increased match of the cued state (i.e., ).

Through Equations (1)-(3), we can determine the probabilities for all state transitions depicted in Figure 1A 2 . Using these transition probabilities, we can compute the overall probability that by the time one arrives in a terminal state, -(which here is going to sleep, % ), the intended goal has been pursued. This overall probability of goal pursuit, &./0 ( ), can be computed using the following recursive equation:

where, = 2: . Equation 4comprises two terms on the right-hand side. The first term is the probability that the goal has already been pursued in a previous state by the time one arrives in the current state (and thus does not need to be pursued anymore). The second term is the probability that the goal was not pursued before arriving in the current state multiplied by the probability that it will be pursued in the current state. Computing this equation iteratively, we can obtain &./0 ( ) as a function of our three proposed parameters-subjective value of the goal ( & ), state-specificity ( ), and the statespecificity suppression exponent ( ). This is depicted in Figure 1B. Figure 1B shows that the probability of pursuing a goal increases monotonically with & when averaged (i.e., marginalised) over the other two parameters. This is unsurprising considering that such a mechanism was explicitly specified in Equation 1. Nonetheless, it shows that our framework accounts for the basic finding of the intention-behaviour correlation literature where a GOI leads to increased goal pursuit compared to the absence of an intention. Importantly, patterns related to the other two parameters are non-trivial and exhibit at least three interesting characteristics that both explain existing findings as well make novel predictions.

First, with sufficiently high values of state-specificity, goal pursual becomes (on average) increasingly more likely when compared to the absence of state specificity (i.e., compared to = 1). Thus, the framework explains the higher likelihood of goal pursuit with IMPIs (i.e., with high state-specificity) compared to GOIs, consistent with the vast volume of existing literature. Importantly, this observation of an IMPI improving goal pursuit over GOI occurs not by simply increasing the match of the goal with the cued context, as is commonly described in existing models of IMPIs 7,58 . Instead, within our proposed framework an increased match of the goal with the cued context is accompanied by a suppression in its match with the non-cued contexts, where the suppression would lead to a reduction in likelihood of goal pursuit. We find that, on average, goal pursual becomes more likely with IMPI despite these opposing influences.

In our framework, we implement increased match of the goal with cued contexts by multiplying its match with and a suppression of match with non-cued contexts by dividing their match by , . Here, higher values of heighten the suppression of noncued contexts. Interestingly, beyond a certain degree of state-specificity ( > 10), IMPIs lead to higher goal pursuit than GOIs irrespective of the suppression in match with the non-cued contexts (i.e., irrespective of ). This implies that forming sufficiently strong links between specific contexts and goal pursuit may be considered an optimal means of goal pursuit despite the costs associated with forming them [88][89][90] . Here, the optimality of IMPIs is yet more buttressed by the fact that IMPIs increase goal pursuit, while at the same time freeing up non-cued contexts for pursuit of other goals.

Second, the framework explains a plethora of (seemingly contradictory) findings on moderators of IMPIs. In Figure 1B, the lower three set of curves show that as subjective value of the goal ( & ) increases, the slope of goal pursuit in relation to state-specificity increases. This pattern explains observations of a larger impact of IMPIs on goal pursuit in relation to stronger GOIs (one interpretation of & is the magnitude of GOI) 61,67-72 . For example, Sheeran et al (2005) investigated the interplay of GOIs and IMPIs in relation to the number of hours student participants engaged in study. They used the number of hours student participants intended to engage in study for the upcoming week as the baseline magnitude of GOIs. This was supplemented by an additional effect of IMPI on study hours for that week 61 . Their findings presented in Sheeran et al (2005) Figure 1 are qualitatively very similar to the lower three curves of our Figure 1B (greenish colours), both of which show a larger increase in goal pursuit for IMPI compared to GOI with larger baseline GOI values. Conversely, the upper three set of curves in Figure 1B (reddish colours) show the opposite pattern. Here, the slope of goal pursuit with state-subjectivity decreases as & increases. This section of the plot shows that when goals are generally achievable with a high probability, there is little-to-no benefit of IMPIs. And where goal pursuit is already at ceiling, IMPIs are even predicted to reduce goal pursuit compared to GOIs (due to suppression of goal pursuit in non-cued states). This pattern is corroborated by several studies on moderation of IMPIs by task difficulty 34,54,74 such that easier tasks are less benefited by IMPIs (where, & is inversely related to difficulty). A similar observation is made when investigating IMPIs in relation to personality factors like conscientiousness, which drive people to perform certain tasks at ceiling. For example, the upper three curves of Figure 1B are qualitatively similar to Figure 1 from Webb et al (2007), which shows a moderation of the effect of IMPIs on goal pursuit by conscientiousness. Interestingly, they found that goal pursuit was hampered by IMPIs for the most conscientious people who were already at ceiling, as predicted by our framework 73 . Our framework also makes testable predictions for future work in relation to moderators of IMPIs. Specifically, if the framework is correct, we expect that moderating effects of factors like strength of GOI and ease of goal pursuit on how IMPI impact goal pursuit would depend on which region of goal pursuit likelihood a study is operating within (i.e., more close to the floor or ceiling of &./0 ( )) 74 .

Third, for many curves in Figure 1B, we observe a small initial dip in goal pursuit with an increase in state-specificity. In other words, our framework predicts that for people who increase the match of the cued state with the goal only by a small degree goal pursuit will be hampered by formation of an IMPI. This dip can be thought of as a "side-effect" of the reduction of match with non-cued contexts on &./0 ( ), which becomes larger with larger values the suppression exponent, . The possibility of such a dip in goal pursual is a novel and empirically testable contribution of our framework, with its mechanistic source rooted in past work on suppressed match of the goal with non-cued contexts [77][78][79] . This parameter has the potential to explain several suboptimalities of goal pursuit in relation to how individuals may potentially "offload" goal pursuit to the contextual cue specified in the IMPI 94,95 . For example, some individuals may be overconfident in their ability to pursue goals in the cued context. These individuals may have a very high , where they suppress goal pursual in non-cued scenarios to a very high degree 96,97 . As a result, if they miss goal pursuit in relation to the cued context (e.g., if the cue is omitted from the environment 78 ), they will also miss pursuing the goal in non-cued scenarios. Conversely, other individuals may be underconfident in their ability to pursue goals in the cued contexts 96 . These individuals may have a very low , leading to unwanted disruption of their routine behaviours due to compulsive thoughts about goal pursuit 77 . Thus, the suppression exponent can be considered in relation to metacognitive aspects of IMPI, where it is impacted by metacognitive biases in relation to how well a person thinks is their ability to pursue a goal in relation to the cued state [98][99][100][101] . Several personality and mental health factors are known to globally bias metacognitive assessments [102][103][104][105][106] , and their impact on goal pursuit through intention formation is relatively unexplored 45 .

div.head: Neurocognitive basis of intention formation
div.p: The computational framework for intention formation we present above is one that is general and agnostic to how its parameters are cognitively and neurally realised. In other words, the framework is valid irrespective of the specific mechanisms through which one sets a goal's value and state-specificity. In this section, we review work that can potentially inform the neurocognitive substrates of our proposed framework.

Recent decades have seen substantial progress in our understanding of neurocognitive mechanisms underlying planning and value-based sequential decision making. An influential branch of this work has formalised how human, animal, as well as artificial agents choose upcoming behaviours in expectation of reward using reinforcement learning (RL) procedures 107 . RL procedures are commonly categorized into "model-free" and "model-based" variants [107][108][109][110] . In model-free RL, associations between sequences of behaviours (e.g., between cues and actions) are formed (and strengthened) when the sequence leads to a rewarding outcome (a proxy for a goal). While model-free RL is closely linked to habitual or automatic behaviours 108 , it is unlike the kind of instant habits formation proposed to underlie IMPIs. This is because in model-free behaviour, reward (akin to value of the intended goal), and associations between expected upcoming states (akin to match of the intended goal with contextual cues) are inextricably linked. However, as we review above, for IMPIs a goal's value and its associations with contextual cues are, to a large extent, independent 7,9,10,56 . In model-based RL, an agent forms a map (i.e., model) of its environment to choose the best (i.e., most rewarding) sequences of behaviours 107 . Model-based RL is linked to deliberative or intentional processes because it allows the flexibility to make decisions that incorporate previously unencountered associations between behaviours 108 . However, because model-based behaviours involve parsing complex decision trees of upcoming outcomes and rewards at decision-time, they are not immediate and do not have the instant-habit-like character of IMPIs. Thus, model-free and model-based procedures are unlikely to fully explain intention formation, especially IMPIs.

What may inform intention formation in the context of IMPIs is recent work on successor representations 111,112 . Successor representations are predictive maps where associations between sequential behavioural states that are formed not based on reward but based on adjacency of behavioural states (e.g., spatial, temporal, or conceptual adjacency). Here, the associative strength between states depends on the regularity with which one state is "visited" following another 112,113 . Such associations can be formed not only by visiting adjacent states experientially, but also through mental simulations of a predicted map of the states obtained from long-term memory 113,114 . Such a mental simulation account is very similar to the one posited to underlie IMPIs where mental simulations are used to associate cues with the goal pursuit 58,93 . Successor representations can be combined with expected reward of the upcoming states to decide which behaviour to choose rapidly and in a non-computationally-intensive manner akin to habitual behaviour 113,114 . This process also parallels descriptions of IMPIs-including our proposed framework in the previous section-where associations between states are combined with subjective value of the goal (or GOIs) to pursue upcoming behaviour in a single processing step. Furthermore, recent empirical work has shown that successor representations explain decoupling of states and reward observed in human behaviour, which is not explained by model-free and model-based RL accounts 113 . Thus, successor representations are a good candidate mechanism for realising the state-specificity ( ) and suppression exponent parameters ( ) in our proposed framework. In other words, when a person forms an IMPI, they effectively modify their predicted cognitive map of how future states are associated with each other such that the cued state is more closely associated with the goal, while the non-cued states are less associated with the goal. As a result, upon encountering the cue, its association with the goal is a highly likely successor state. In the brain, successor representations are posited to be realised within the hippocampus in the form of a predictive cognitive map of one's environment 21,30,115,116 . Thus, the hippocampus would be a key brain region involved in intention formation, particularly in relation to a cognitive map of future states within which to define an IMPI ( Table 1 summarises the potential neurocognitive substrates for our proposed computational parameters underlying intention formation). Besides the map itself, we would also expect the involvement of executive brain regions to navigate the map and identify appropriate contexts to cue the goal in. A substantial literature points to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex's critical involvement in planning 23,27,117,118 , which we propose would be involved in identifying the precise future contextual cues for linking to goal pursuit 31 .

With regards to the proposed subjective value of the goal parameter, 2 , a recent study has shown that the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex may represent prospective value of decisions in the context of planning 31 . Additionally, a wealth of neurocognitive literature has associated diverse types of subjective value and reward signals 119,120 with orbitofrontal cortex [121][122][123] , ventromedial prefrontal cortex 119,120,124,125 , and ventral striatum 119,120,126 . A network of these regions may thus be involved in evaluating the subjective value of the goal and the predicted routine states.

Finally, as we proposed in the previous section, the suppression exponent would have a metacognitive component such that people will suppress goal pursuit in non-cued states based on their assessment of how likely they are to follow-up on the goal in the cued state. Metacognitive abilities are most commonly linked to the rostral prefrontal cortex (rPFC) , including those related to prospective metacognitive judgements [127][128][129][130] . At the same time, metacognitive biases are linked to the ventral striatum 129,[131][132][133][134] . These regions would thus likely have a role in formulating metacognitive aspects of the suppression exponent for an individual in concert with the hippocampus.

div.head: Future directions and limitations
div.p: Our model opens a plethora of avenues for future work.

One series of future studies could use existing social and applied psychology paradigms to test novel predictions of our framework with regards to how plan-specificity through IMPIs makes goal pursuit more and less likely than GOIs. A few of these predictions are outlined in Section 3. For example, our framework predicts that the moderating effect of GOIs on the increase in goal pursuit by IMPIs depends on whether the goal is generally achievable or not. Whereas stronger GOIs would increase the effect of IMPIs for relatively challenging goals, they would decrease the effect of IMPIs for easily achievable goals. While different studies support prediction, a formal test of this idea in a single study is currently missing.

Future work can also focus on testing predictions of our novel suppression exponent parameter, which relates to the degree with which goal pursuit is offloaded to the cued context such that it is less likely to be pursued in the non-cued contexts. While this parameter is motivated by previous work showing that formation of IMPIs can lead to reduction in goal pursuit in non-cued contexts [77][78][79] and the idea of cognitive offloading more generally 94 , it has not previously been considered a mechanistic feature of IMPIs.

The presence of such a mechanism predicts several unexplored suboptimalities in goal pursuit. For example, metacognitive biases associated with personality or mental-healthrelated factors may lead people to overestimate or underestimate their likelihood of goal pursuit in the cued context, leading to differences in the degree to which they suppress goal pursuit in the non-cued contexts. With overestimation, goal pursuit would be hampered in situations where there is a possibility of missing the cued state [77][78][79] . And underestimation may lead to lead compulsive thoughts and anxiety about the goal 135,136 .

Another avenue forward would be through a computational psychiatry approach, which allows us to empirically estimate the proposed computational parameters for intention formation for an individual. These parameters can then be used to investigate precise computational mechanisms underlying deficits in goal pursuit and intention formation in relation to relevant personality and mental health factors. Such an approach would require developing experimental paradigms where the different parameters are manipulated within individuals (currently, a majority of research on intention formation is conducted using between-individual or mixed research designs). These experimental paradigms can be developed, for example, using event-related prospective memory paradigms that incorporate IMPI strategies [137][138][139][140] .

Finally, currently the neural bases of intention formation are relatively unexplored. A few past studies have used fMRI to measure neural correlates of holding delayed intentions related to choice 141,142 , prospective memory 137,[143][144][145][146][147] , goals 137,148 , and action plans 148 . A common observation across these studies is the recruitment of rPFC in holding delayed intentions. With respect to the proposed framework, neural correlates of such delayed intentions would mainly to correspond to retaining GOIs in mind while doing other (e.g., routine) tasks. One study has used fMRI to investigate differences between retrieving goals linked to IMPIs and GOIs 137 . The study found that accurate retrieval of GOIs and IMPIs recruited lateral and medial rPFC respectively, which was interpreted as higher vs. lower cognitive demands in retrieving intentions. No study (to our knowledge) has investigated neural mechanisms underlying intentions formation. Future studies can do so by identifying the neural sources/networks that underpin our proposed computational parameters with hypotheses outlined in Table 1.

A limitation of our framework is the independence assumption of our proposed computational parameters. We show above that despite such an assumption our framework explains existing empirical findings that seemingly exhibit dependencies between the effect of IMPIs (or state-specificity) and subjective value on goal pursuit. Nonetheless, there may be potential dependencies, for example, between a goal's value and the degree to which its pursuit is suppressed in non-cued states (the suppression exponent). Future work can identify such dependences and appropriately extend our proposed framework by decomposing the suppression exponent parameter into valuedependent and value-independent components. Here, the proposed behaviour of the suppression exponent would still hold in relation to the value-independent component.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: We propose a general computational framework based in normative cognitive principles of resource rationality to explain how people form Goal and Implementation Intentions, and how such intention formation relates to whether and to what degree people pursue a goal in the future. Our framework operationalises three parameters: 1) the subjective value of a goal, 2) its state-specificity or the degree to which one expects to pursue it cued by a specific context in the future, and 3) the degree to which people suppress goal pursuit in non-cued contexts. Such a framework explains a large volume of social, cognitive, and applied psychology literature on Goal and Implementation Intentions, while formalising conditions under which a Goal or an Implementation Intention may be an optimal strategy for successful goal pursuit. Finally, we discuss avenues for a future neurocomputational science of intention formation.

div.head: Box 1 -Intention formation and intention retrieval
div.p: We have recently proposed a Model of Intention Selection (MIS), which is a computational account of how one of several competing action representations in longterm memory become active in working memory 91,92 . Here, action representations include voluntary intentions, partially automatized routines, and involuntary habits. While the framework proposed in the present paper is one of how intentions are formed or set, the MIS is a model of how intentions are retrieved at choice time -the two being conceptually distinct but related processes 149 . Here, we show how the parameters of our proposed computational framework relate to those of the MIS.
In the MIS, the competition between action representations may be understood as a stochastic race analogous to the architecture of some formal models of visual attention 150

where the matching parameter, ψ(χ, ), is the contextual support in the environment for action representation χ having component ∈ . The importance factor, ω 9 ∑ ω ⁄ , represents the relative weight of action representation χ compared to the set of all competing action representations including χ.

For simplicity, here we assume that the bias parameter, Β 6 , is the same for all action representations and components, and can therefore be set to a value of 1.0 without loss of generality. Further, we define the rate of processing of the action representation as the sum of the rate of the components, i.e., λ(χ) = ∑ λ(χ, )
. This corresponds to assuming that the first component finishing processing effectively secures the action representation as the winner. The simplified rate equation is then given by λ(χ) = ψ(χ)

Assuming that processing is exponential 92 , the probability that an action representation χ is the first to become active in working memory (i.e. winning the race) can be derived to be (χ) = :(9) ∑ :(=)

We can use Equations (B) and (C) to describe competition between intentions (GOIs or IMPIs) and routines in a sequence in relation to the example of call a friend depicted in Figure 1A. Let ' be the current state in the routine sequence ! , … , % and let '(! be the subsequent routine state in the sequence. Further, let & be the goal state of calling one's friend. We can derive the probabilities of selecting either of the two action representations corresponding to states & or '(! . Specifically, the probability of choosing the intention rather than the routine is given by

If the importance weights ω > and ω ?(! in Equation (D) are substituted with value parameters & and '(! , Equation 1 follows directly. In empirical data we find that ω relates to reward ( ) through an exponential function 92 , though the precise form of relationship between the two does not impact generalisation of either model.

Each action representation χ can have three components = { 3 , 4 , 5 }, where S = stimulus, R = response, and P = propositional goal. MIS proposes that a rate equation specifies the rate of processing, λ(χ, ), of component of action representation χ as, λ(χ, ) = ψ(χ, )Β

body.note: We refer to it as a computational framework rather than a computational model because of its very general nature and because it can be realised using a number of more specific computational models, as discussed in Section 4.

For simplicity, in our simulation, we assume that the value and contextual match of selecting subsequent routine states from a preceding routine state are equal to one ( !"# = 1, !"# = 1). This assumption is made without losing generalisation of the qualitative patterns depicted inFigure 1.

div.p: Authors declare no competing interests.
